references: In the existing literature, there are many metrics available to measure exposure fairness in recommender systems (Raj and Ekstrand, 2022; Singh and Joachims, 2018; Zehlike and Castillo, 2020; Heuss et al., 2022; Liu et al., 2024). In this study, our focus is on assessing exposure fairness through various dimensions within the family of exposure metrics. Specifically, we scrutinize two critical dimensions: (i) consideration or disregard of the item’s position in the recommendation list (w/ or w/o position, respectively), and (ii) allocation of exposure proportionately or irrespective of items’ merit (w/ or w/o merit, respectively). Table (Raj and Ekstrand, 2022; Singh and Joachims, 2018; Zehlike and Castillo, 2020; Heuss et al., 2022; Liu et al., 2024). In this study, our focus is on assessing exposure fairness through various dimensions within the family of exposure metrics. Specifically, we scrutinize two critical dimensions: (i) consideration or disregard of the item’s position in the recommendation list (w/ or w/o position, respectively), and (ii) allocation of exposure proportionately or irrespective of items’ merit (w/ or w/o merit, respectively). Table 1 provides an overview of four distinct notions of exposure based on these dimensions.1 11 11Merit, in this context, refers to any quality measure for items, such as relevance (Balagopalan et al., 2023). The definition of the merit measure employed in this paper is elucidated in Section (Balagopalan et al., 2023). The definition of the merit measure employed in this paper is elucidated in Section 5.

Exposure fairness, as we define it, refers to the equitable distribution of exposure among items. With an exposure distribution representing the allocated exposure value for each item, our objective is to assess the extent to which this distribution achieves uniformity, with a uniform distribution being deemed the fairest. The Gini index (Antikacioglu and Ravi, 2017; Vargas and Castells, 2014) is a well-known metric to measure the uniformity of a distribution. Given that the Gini index falls within the range of (Antikacioglu and Ravi, 2017; Vargas and Castells, 2014) is a well-known metric to measure the uniformity of a distribution. Given that the Gini index falls within the range of [ 0 , 1 ] 0 1 [0,1] [ 0 , 1 ] , for consistency, we report 1 minus the Gini index in this paper. Consequently, a Gini index value of 1 signifies the fairest outcome, while a value of 0 denotes the most unfair outcome. It must meet two criteria: 1) positively weight clicked items at the bottom more than those at the top, and 2) negatively weight unclicked items at the top more than those at the bottom. In this paper, we consider three different weight functions, outlined in Table 2, which align with established browsing models (Srikant et al., 2010). For example, the logarithmic function follows the standard exposure drop-off  (Srikant et al., 2010). For example, the logarithmic function follows the standard exposure drop-off (Singh and Joachims, 2018) used in ranking metrics (e.g., nDCG), while the exponential function follows Rank-Biased Precision (RBP)  (Singh and Joachims, 2018) used in ranking metrics (e.g., nDCG), while the exponential function follows Rank-Biased Precision (RBP) (Moffat and Zobel, 2008). Figure  (Moffat and Zobel, 2008). Figure 1 shows the reward distribution of CB and EACB for different weight functions, showcasing the varying intensities of weighting assigned to observed clicked items. The logarithmic function exhibits the highest intensity, followed by the linear and exponential functions.

In our experimental evaluation, we investigate the impact of integrating our exposure-aware reward model into the linear cascading bandit algorithm (Zong et al., 2016). We compare the performance of this modified algorithm, termed (Zong et al., 2016). We compare the performance of this modified algorithm, termed EALinUCB, with the original linear cascading bandit algorithm (LinUCB), where our reward model is not employed. For brevity, we omit the term ”Cascade” in the names of the algorithms. Additionally, we consider three variations of EALinUCB, each utilizing a different weight function for training, as detailed in Table 2. We also compare EALinUCB with the following baselines:
